title: Narrow the gap
text:
Why narrow the gap?
Many vulnerable individuals and families in Ireland are struggling to make ends meet and are falling into poverty (Roantree et al. 2025). Because government resources are limited and there are many competing demands on social welfare funding, it is crucial to understand ‘who’ supports State efforts to reduce income inequalities and to provide welfare, as well as examine ‘when’ and ‘why’ they support these efforts.

title: Narrow the gap
text:
Who supports redistribution?









According to data from the Euorpean Social Survey, three in every four Irish residents agree that the “government should reduce differences in income”.




About 76 per cent of respondents indicated that they either ‘agree’ (45%) or ‘agree strongly’ (31%) with this statement.




This proportion is slightly higher than the European average (71%) and the ones from other northern European countries.


























Both female respondents and those who place themselves on the left of the left-right political scale are more likely to support income redistribution, even when controlling for other factors such as age and education.
Overall, the examination of individual factors associated with support for income redistribution in Ireland goes in the same direction of the literature pointing out the role of material interests (financial situation) and perspectives of upward mobility (social class) (Bonnet et al. 2024).

title: Public support for welfare and redistributive policies in Ireland
text:
Taxes
1 in 3
Irish residents indicated that they agree with higher taxes if it means more or better public services. This is the 6th highest percentage across 27 EU countries.


Source: Authors’ own analysis of the Eurobarometer Flash Survey 2025.

Social benefits



More than half of Irish residents agree that social benefits make people lazy.





Source: Authors’ own analysis of the European Social Survey 2009/2016.

title: Public support for welfare and redistributive policies in Ireland
text:
Relevant events



Those who experienced job loss during the COVID19 pandemic are more supportive of redistribution, regardless of their financial situation or social class.





Source: Authors’ own analysis of the European Social Survey 2023/2024.

title: Public support for welfare and redistributive policies in Ireland
text:
Societal level influences

Higher support for redistribution in countries with higher inequality (Velev and Schmidt-Catran 2024; Finseraas 2009)
Support for redistribution remained apparently stable over time (Lupu and Pontusson 2023) and could be related to lack of major political reaction to income inequality.

title: Public support for welfare and redistributive policies in Ireland
text:
Socio-demographic predictors

Women are more progressive in relation to policy preferences and support for redistribution (Shorrocks and Grasso 2020; Inglehart 2018; Grasso and Shorrocks 2025)
Steele, Cohen, and Van Der Naald (2022) find that older respondents are more favourable of income redistribution.
Grasso and Shorrocks (2025) highlights the association between gender and generation, with the cohorts of women born after 1946 being more supportive of redistribution compared to men in their cohorts

title: Public support for welfare and redistributive policies in Ireland
text:
Welfare for whom?
Oorschot and Roosma (2017) note that support for welfare policies, social transfers and redistribution is conditional on the social legitimacy of these policies’ target groups
